definition: to starve to death/to be very hungry
fullness for the bold, famine for the timid (idiom)
pinyin: cheng1 si3 dan3 da4 de5 , e4 si3 dan3 xiao3 de5
containing_words.word: 撐死膽大的，餓死膽小的

sentences.english: July 14 ghosts door open, short-lived starve not vegetarian dish called jai.
sentences.chinese: 七月十四鬼門開，短命餓死不喫齋。

sentences.english: As shallow-water plants, phytoplankton are therefore starving to death, according to the findings.
sentences.chinese: 根據該研究，浮游植物爲淺水植物，因而餓死。

sentences.english: The poor unfortunate had starved to death .
sentences.chinese: 這個可憐的倒黴蛋是餓死的。

sentences.english: We're starving, and would you mind hurrying?
sentences.chinese: 我們都要餓死了，能快點兒嗎？

sentences.english: We are starving. Would you please hurry up?
sentences.chinese: 我們都要餓死了，能快點兒嗎？

sentences.english: No, for there was millet plus pickles.
sentences.chinese: 沒有餓死，還有小米加酸菜。

sentences.english: The proud man said he would starve rather than beg for food.
sentences.chinese: 那個驕傲的人說他寧願餓死也不願討飯。

sentences.english: A cockroach can live  several weeks with its head cut off--it dies from starvation.
sentences.chinese: 蟑螂在被砍頭之後還能活幾個星期，最後死也是餓死。

sentences.english: The Internet can also serve to starve off boredom and keep the mind active in the later years of life.
sentences.chinese: 互聯網還可以餓死了煩惱和保持思維活躍的晚年生活。

sentences.english: A shallow-minded people like me is always work for money only.
sentences.chinese: 膚淺如我，工作只是爲了不讓自己餓死而已。

sentences.english: But cancer isn’t the only disease that anti-angiogenesis can starve.
sentences.chinese: 但癌症並非唯一抗血管生成可餓死的疾病。

sentences.english: The poor dog had no aliment, it was dying.
sentences.chinese: 可憐的狗不食品，快要餓死了。

sentences.english: Sages pure and austere, die embracing lone mountains.
sentences.chinese: 詩人多清峭，餓死抱空山。

definition: to have a meal/to eat/to make a living
poor/destitute/to use up/to exhaust/thoroughly/extremely/(coll.) persistently and pointlessly
to say again/to put off a discussion until later/moreover/what's more/besides
preferably/one would prefer to...(or not to...)/would rather/(would) be better to/(to pick) the lesser of two evils
we or us (including both the speaker and the person(s) spoken to)/(dialect) I or me/(dialect) (in a coaxing or familiar way) you/also pr. [za2 men5]
to close a door/to lock a door/(of a shop etc) to close (for the night, or permanently)
just in case/if by any chance/contingency
